importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the Blue Jays defeated the Mariners in the ALCS, forcing a Game 7 and advancing to the World Series.
The date when the Mariners previously scored five runs in four innings against Yesavage in Game 2, marking a turning point in the series.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which the Mariners' performance declined, culminating in their elimination from the ALCS after the Blue Jays' decisive 6-2 win.

keyTakeAways: Vladimir Guerrero Jr. hit his sixth home run of the postseason, extending the Blue Jays' lead to 5-0 and sealing the series.
The Seattle Mariners committed three errors, including two in the second inning, which led directly to early runs for Toronto.
The Blue Jays' victory forces a Game 7 in the ALCS, marking the first time Seattle has played a decisive Game 7 in its history.
The Blue Jays have played a Game 7 only twice in their history, with the most recent being in 1985.
Randy Arozerana's single in the sixth inning allowed Trey Yesavage to be removed after 87 pitches, highlighting a pivotal defensive moment.
Trey Yesavage delivered a strong performance on the mound, throwing 31 splitters and allowing only six hits and three walks, showing composure under pressure.
The Blue Jays will face the Los Angeles Dodgers in the World Series, with Game 1 set for Friday.
The game was won in large part due to defensive lapses by the Mariners and a dominant offensive performance by Toronto, especially by Guerrero Jr. and Barger.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Guerrero Jr.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He hit his sixth home run of the postseason, a pivotal moment that extended the Blue Jays’ lead and sealed the ALCS series.

namedEntities.name: Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays won the game 6-2 and forced a decisive Game 7 in the ALCS, marking their return to a critical playoff stage.

namedEntities.name: Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners were defeated 6-2 and will play Game 7 for the first time in history, indicating a major shift in their postseason trajectory.

namedEntities.name: American League Championship Series (ALCS)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ALCS determines the American League champion, and this game forced a Game 7, setting up a World Series matchup.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The winner of the ALCS will face the Dodgers in the World Series, highlighting the postseason's national significance.

namedEntities.name: Randy Arozerana

namedEntities.name: Julio Rodríguez

namedEntities.name: Eugenio Suárez
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He lost possession of a ground ball during a transfer throw, leading to a run and a key defensive mistake.

namedEntities.name: Addison Barger

namedEntities.name: Daulton Varsho

namedEntities.name: Ernie Clement
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He hit a groundball that led to a defensive error by Eugenio Suárez, resulting in a run for the Blue Jays.

namedEntities.name: Matt Brash

namedEntities.name: John Schneider

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Toronto Blue Jays defeated the Seattle Mariners 6-2 in a pivotal game of the 2025 American League Championship Series, forcing a decisive Game 7. Vladimir Guerrero Jr. hit his sixth postseason home run, extending the lead and sealing the series. The Mariners committed three critical errors, including two in the second inning, which allowed Toronto to score early. Key performances included Addison Barger’s two-run homer and Trey Yesavage’s strong pitching, who threw 31 splitters and limited runs. The Blue Jays’ victory marks their first Game 7 since 1985 and sets up a World Series matchup against the Los Angeles Dodgers, with Game 1 scheduled for Friday.
title: Vladimir Guerrero Jr. hits sixth homer of postseason as Blue Jays dominate Mariners to force ALCS Game 7
